35. equitum turmae: turma is the term regularly used for a division of Roman cavalry. lt is used also, however, as a general term for the cavalry of other nations, and is to be understood here of the Caledonians. Agricola's cavalry, consisting of auxiliaries, is spoken of in the next chapter as alae, the regular expression for auxiliary cavalry.

22. 2. recentem terrorem, etc: the war-chariots at first caused some confusion among the assaulting party (the Romans), but soon became useless on the hilly ground, and mixed in with the thick ranks of their own countrymen3 hostium must, from Tacitus' point of view, be the Caledoniam.

4. minime equestris: the ground not being suited to horses‚ this battle of the war-chariots, which would properly be ranked with cavalry engagements, became minime equestris. The same ex- pression, minime equestris more pugnae, is used by Livy (xxii. 47) with reference to the battle of Cannas, where, as here, the horse became useless from the closeness of the action and the nature of the ground.

5. aegre olivo astantes: the manuscripts read egra diu aut stante; manifestly corrupt. Kritz reads clivo instantee; Halm and Draeger, adstantes. lt will be noted that in the round hand of the manuscripts cliv could be easily mistaken for diu. This ap· pears to refer to the Caledonians3 while the following indicative clause, ae saepe ...incursabant describes both parties ln this difficult passage, Kritz (following Wex) reads aequa nostris for equestres of the manuscripts, and metantes for aut stante, making the confusion refer to the Romans. lt is evident, however, frorn the following chapter, circumire terga vincentium, that the Romans were successful so far, and were making their way trium- phantly up the hill. The events of the battle had been as follows: first, the skirmishing eminus, next, the assault made hythe Bata- vians and Tungrians3 third, the joining of the war-chariots in the battle, after the cavalry had been routed (Interim . . . haerebant). Then follows a description of the mixed nature of the battle (mini- meque . . . impellerentur), and the confusion caused by the frightened horses (ae saepe ...incursabant).
